questions.question: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic because of walking difficulties. His mother says hehas always walked on his toes and walks by tilting side-to-side. He also has progressivemuscle weakness. There is no history of trauma, fever, or rash. On examination, calfhypertrophy with atrophied thigh muscles is noted as shown below. There is no tenderness onpalpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
The image below shows the model of a skeletal muscle fiber. Which of the followingstructures is affected in Duchenne muscular dystrophy?691
questions.explanation: The structure marked as B in the image represents dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein),which is absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophingene.This gene is located on the short arm of chromosome X near the p21 locus (Xp21). Lack ofdystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellularcomponents.The Dystrophin-glycoprotein complexSarcoglycancomplexOMARROW698-Dystrophin-associatedcomplex-Dystrophin-ActinMyofibril

questions.question: Abhi, a young boy is being evaluated in the ward for proximal muscle weakness. Waddlinggait and Gowers sign are observed in this child. Genetic analysis confirms the diagnosis asDuchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the following is false regarding this patient'scondition?

options.A: It is less severe than Becker's dystrophy
options.B: Tendon reflexes are lost after age 6
options.C: Gene affected is the largest gene in humans

questions.explanation: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is more severe than Becker's dystrophy. In DMD, tendon reflexesare lost after age 6.Becker's dystrophy is similar to Duchenne muscular dystrophy with a genetic defect at the samelocus (Xp21) but clinically less severe. Gene affected in both is dystrophin, which is the largestgene in humans.Important differences between Duchenne and Becker's muscular dystrophy:OnsetDuchenne's dystrophyAge: 2-3 yearsBecker's dystrophyAge: 5-15 yearsWeaknessProgressiveIntellectual impairmenCommonVariableUncommontPrognosisWheelchair dependant by adolescenceAmbulatory till early adult lifeDeathBy the age of 18-20 yearsBy 40s or 50s

questions.question: You observe a six-year-old child in the ward and notice the following. Which of the followingare true regarding this sign?692
questions.explanation: The image shows the Gowers sign. Patients use their hands to "climb up" their legs when asked torise from a prone position to compensate for proximal lower-extremity weakness. An early Gowerssign is often evident by age of 3 years and is fully expressed by age of 5 or 6 years.This maneuver can be seen in patients with:• Duchenne muscular dystrophy•Becker's muscular dystrophy• Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy• Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy• Polymyositis• Dermatomyositis699Gower's sign©MARROW

questions.question: A concerned mother brought her son to the clinic because of difficulty writing in school. Shealsosays that his eyes remain partially open when he sleeps. There is no history of trauma orsurgery. On examination, he has asymmetric wrist and finger weakness. The mouth appearspuckered and rounded, deltoid muscles are flattened and the following finding is observed.What is the likely diagnosis?693
questions.explanation: The image shows winging of the scapula, which when combined with this patient's features aresuggestive of facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy.Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant condition that generally presents withasymmetric weakness in facial and shoulder girdle muscles. Occasionally, finger and wristweakness is the first symptom.The mouth is rounded and appears puckered because of the protruding lips. Upper facialweakness will manifest as an inability to close the eyes completely in sleep. Scapular winging isprominent, even in infants. Flattening or even concavity of the deltoid contour is seen, and thebiceps and triceps brachii muscles are wasted and weak. Eventually, proximal muscles getinvolved and undergo atrophy, and Gowers sign & Trendelenburg gait appear. Lumbarlordosis, foot drop, and kyphoscoliosis are common complications.Treatment includes orthopedic measures for scoliosis and foot drop, surgical intervention forscapular deformity. Physiotherapy has no value.Other options:Long thoracic nerve palsy: No history of trauma or surgery rules out this diagnosis.Klippel-Feil syndrome: Classic triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome (congenital musculoskeletalcondition)•⚫ low posterior hairline•⚫ short neck⚫ decreased cervical range of motionMyotonic dystrophy patients have a characteristic V-shaped upper lip, a history of myotonia, andprogressive weakness.700

questions.question: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently,there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations arenormal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture showing pain in the calves occuring within a week of an upper respiratorytract infection (URI), with elevated creatine kinase levels suggests the diagnosis of viral myositis.The specific history of URI suggests influenza myositis.Infectious myositis has a male predominance and is typically seen in young adults. Childhoodform presents with fever, malaise, and rhinorrhea and is usually followed by severe pain,especially in the calves. The muscle pain is usually worse with movement and the symptoms lastfor about a week. In children, toe walking and wide-based gait may be seen because of theinvolvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.Other viral causes of myositis include HIV-1 (one of the most common causes of myositis), groupB coxsackievirus (epidemic myalgia), HTLV-1 (Human T-lymphotropic virus), andcytomegalovirus (CMV).Lab features of influenza myositis include elevated CK which may be as high as 500 times normalthe value. Urine myoglobin is usually positive. Detection of the virus with PCR testing ofnasopharyngeal specimens can be carried out but is not of much clinical significance. Thehistopathological examination would reveal muscle fiber necrosis without much inflammatorychange.Treatment includes bed rest, IV fluids, and symptomatic management with analgesics andantipyretics. Amantadine and other antiviral agents may be considered in adults. Complicationsinclude myocarditis and respiratory dysfunction. Rhabdomyolysis is an uncommon complication.

questions.question: Rekha brought her 5-day-old infant to the clinic because of feeding difficulties. She says hedoes not latch properly. Her antenatal history is significant for polyhydramnios anddecreased fetal movements. On examination, hypotonia and hyporeflexia are noted in thebaby. which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, only Spinal muscular atrophy presents in infancy. The rest present inlate childhood.Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is a degenerative disease of motor neurons, that is inherited inan autosomal recessive manner. It usually starts in infancy with hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and thinmuscle mass (atrophy). Polyhydramnios may be present prenatally due to weakness inswallowing.Diagnosis is done by genetic testing for SMN gene mutation. Muscle biopsy is done for cases withnegative genetic testing and strong clinical suspicion. The muscle biopsy in infancy shows acharacteristic pattern of perinatal denervation that is unlike that of a mature muscle. Groups ofgiant type I fibers are mixed with fascicles of severely atrophic fibers.Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.Recent updates:• Nusinersen is an antisense oligonucleotide approved by the FDA for treating SMA. It isadministered intrathecally.• Risdiplam (first oral drug) has been approved by FDA to treat infants >2 months of age withSMA. It is an oral splicing modifier that corrects the splicing defect of SMN2, which leads to701increased levels of full-length SMN protein.

questions.question: Pinky, a high school girl, has difficulty in combing her hair and climbing up stairs since 6months. On examination, Gower sign is positive and maculopapular rash present over MCPjoints. What is the next appropriate investigation to be done?694
questions.explanation: A maculopapular rash over the metacarpophalangeal joints is indicative of Gottron papules in achild with proximal muscle weakness is suggestive of juvenile dermatomyositis. As it is aninflammatory myopathy, the next investigation is serum creatine kinase.Though the gold standard investigation is a muscle biopsy, it is indicated only when the diagnosisis in doubt or when grading of the disease severity is required. Nerve conduction studies areusually normal unless associated with severe muscle necrosis and atrophy. Electromyographywould show the characteristic signs of myopathy and muscle fiber necrosis but is preferablyperformed in a specialized center.

questions.question: A 1-day-old girl is being evaluated for decreased muscle tone. On examination, thin cheeks,high arched palate, inverted V-shaped upper lip, and a narrow head are observed. Facialmuscle wasting is prominent. She has a club foot deformity. Her mother has a history ofdelayed relaxation of hand muscles after opening doors. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The patient's clinical features along with the history of myotonia in the mother are suggestive ofMyotonic dystrophy. Facial weakness, inverted V-shaped upper lip, and loss of muscle mass in thetemporal fossae are characteristic of myotonic muscular dystrophy.A severe congenital form of myotonic dystrophy appears in infants born to mothers withsymptomatic myotonic dystrophy. It is inherited as an autosomal-dominant trait. Clinical featuresinclude:• Skeletal deformities (clubfoot deformities alone or congenital contractures involving many jointsand can even include the cervical spine).• Generalized hypotonia and weakness at birth•• Facial wasting and weakness••Inverted V-shaped upper lip• Loss of muscle mass in the temporal fossaInfants can require gavage feeding or ventilator support for respiratory muscle weakness orapnea.Other Options:Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy withhypotonia but has no facial features that are present in this child.In Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the baby appears normal at birth and the facial features presentin this child are not seen.Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy presents with predominant involvement of scapular andhumeral muscles. The given scenario makes this diagnosis less likely.702

questions.question: A small baby who was being evaluated for multiple bone fractures with minor trauma isfound to have brittle bone disease. Which of the following is false regarding this disease?

options.A: It is caused by defects in type 2 collagen.
options.C: Blue sclerae and deafness may be associated.695
options.D: Biphosphonates are useful in the treatment.

questions.explanation: Brittle bone disease is another name for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It is due to defects in type 1collagen, not type 2 collagen.There are 12 types of OI, with type 1 being the most common. Triad of fragile bones, blue sclera,and deafness is known as van der Hoeve syndrome. Treatment includes bisphosphonate therapyand orthopedic rehabilitation.

questions.explanation: White line of Frankel, ground-glass appearance, and zone of rarefaction are the radiological signsseen in scurvy.Radiological signs in scurvy includes:• White line of Frankel: calcified cartilage at metaphyses•Trummerfeld zone: lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line• Pelkan spur: lateral prolongation of the white line, which is present at the cortical ends•Wimberger ring sign: circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers ofossificationSubperiosteal HemorrageScorbutic Zone(Trümmerfeld's zone)Dense Zone ofProvisional Calcification(White line of Frankel)Ring Epiphysis(Wimberger's ring)Pelken's Spur

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant presents with anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. X-ray imaging done asa part of the skeletal survey showed the following image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Anemia and hepatosplenomegaly in an infant with the X-ray image showing dense bones, andbone within the bone appearance is suggestive of osteopetrosis.Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers-Schönberg diseaseIt is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 in osteoclasts.703Clinical features include macrocephaly, developmental delay, anemia (reduced bone marrowcavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis). Low serumcalcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin Dlevels are observed. Radiological features include diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing ofmetaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodiescan be seen (image). Treatment is symptomatic. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can bedone in severe cases.Achondroplasia usually presents with pulmonary symptoms like dyspnea, obstructive sleep apnea,and recurrent infections.In both scurvy and osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), the child cries on touching. On radiography,certain typical features are seen in scurvy, while multiple fractures are seen in OI.704
